cards.title: Roadside America / The disappearing architecture of highways

item.title: Roadside America: the disappearing architecture of highways
item.trailText: The kitsch landscape of American highways before interstates is centre stage at an exhibition by photographer John Margolies.
item.standFirst: The kitsch landscape of American highways before interstates is the focus of an exhibition by John Margolies, who photographed motels, bars, gas stations and fast-food outlets over 30 years. The photos are on display at the Henry Ford Museum in Detroit until 24 January 2016

cards.title: Pakistan heatwave / 'There is no longer space for the bodies'
cards.rawTitle: 'There is no longer space for the bodies'

item.title: Pakistan heatwave: 'There is no longer space for the bodies'
item.trailText: Towards the end of June, more than 750 people died due to a heatwave around the southern port city of Karachi, Pakistan
item.standFirst: Towards the end of June, more than 750 people died due to a heatwave around the southern port city of Karachi, Pakistan. Tens of thousands were treated for heatstroke and dehydration. Medical officials were overwhelmed with the number of bodies, and storage for the mounting body bags became unmanageable. With temperatures reaching 45C (113F), many sick and elderly people, especially from low-income families, were at the highest risk of succumbing to the heat. Madeeha Syed reports
item.byline: Zayar Hassan, Madeeha Syed and Saad Iqbal Toor

cards.title: Wheels of fortune / Tour de France 2015: stage ten

item.title: Tour de France 2015: stage ten
item.trailText: All the best images from stage ten, a 167 km mountain stage between Tarbes and La Pierre-Saint-Martin
item.standFirst: All the best images from stage ten, a 167 km trip between Tarbes and La Pierre-Saint-Martin. It’s the first mountain stage of this year’s tour, finishing with a punishing climb up the Col de Soudet to La Pierre-Saint-Martin in the Pyrenees

cards.title: The wish list / Hand luggage for city breaks and short trips
cards.rawTitle: Hand luggage for city breaks and short trips

item.title: Hand luggage: the wish list
item.trailText: City breaks and short trips begin with your luggage. Go for a zany cartoon print or maybe one that’s got puckered lips all over it…
item.standFirst: City breaks and short trips begin with your luggage. Wheels, telescopic handle and just enough space for a change of clothes. Usually these cases are black and very sensible, but that’s no way to get you into the holiday spirit. Go for a zany cartoon print or maybe one that’s got puckered lips all over it…

cards.title: Pluto probe / Stephen Hawking congratulates Nasa's New Horizons team
cards.rawTitle: Stephen Hawking congratulates Nasa's New Horizons team

item.title: Stephen Hawking congratulates Nasa's New Horizons team on reaching Pluto
item.trailText: British physicist Stephen Hawking praises Nasa's 'pioneering, decade-long mission' after the New Horizons spacecraft completed a dramatic flyby of Pluto, considered the last unexplored world in our solar system
item.standFirst:
British physicist Stephen Hawking praises Nasa's 'pioneering, decade-long mission' after the New Horizons spacecraft completed a dramatic flyby of Pluto, considered the last unexplored world in our solar system. The probe's journey to reach the dwarf planet spanned nine years and a distance of three billion miles (4.8bn km)

Read an in-depth report here

stillImage.caption: Message from Prof Stephen Hawking to congratulate the New Horizons teams on reaching Pluto. 15 July 2015 Photograph: Nasa Photograph: Nasa
stillImage.cleanCaption: Message from Prof Stephen Hawking to congratulate the New Horizons teams on reaching Pluto. 15 July 2015 Photograph: Nasa

displayImages.caption: Message from Prof Stephen Hawking to congratulate the New Horizons teams on reaching Pluto. 15 July 2015 Photograph: Nasa Photograph: Nasa
displayImages.cleanCaption: Message from Prof Stephen Hawking to congratulate the New Horizons teams on reaching Pluto. 15 July 2015 Photograph: Nasa

image.caption: Message from Prof Stephen Hawking to congratulate the New Horizons teams on reaching Pluto. 15 July 2015 Photograph: Nasa Photograph: Nasa
image.cleanCaption: Message from Prof Stephen Hawking to congratulate the New Horizons teams on reaching Pluto. 15 July 2015 Photograph: Nasa

cards.title: China's 'face-kini' / Popular with those averse to jellyfish stings and tans
cards.rawTitle: Popular with those averse to jellyfish stings and tans

item.title: China's 'face-kini' proves popular for those averse to jellyfish stings and tans
item.trailText: Zhang Shifan, owner of a swimwear store in Qingdao, eastern China, says she invented the 'face-kini' in 2004, when customers asked for a swim mask that offered protection from jellyfish stings and getting a tan
item.standFirst: Zhang Shifan, owner of a swimwear store in Qingdao, eastern China, says she invented the 'face-kini' in 2004, when customers asked for a swim mask that offered protection from jellyfish stings and getting a tan. While she now has a loyal following, Zhang says the garment has the undesirable side effect of scaring away children. Others now produce similar masks but loyal customers like Wang Baoyu say nothing beats the original

stillImage.caption: Woman invents the 'face-kini' for those afraid of jellyfish stings and tanning. 15 July 2015 Photograph: Reuters Photograph: Reuters
stillImage.cleanCaption: Woman invents the 'face-kini' for those afraid of jellyfish stings and tanning. 15 July 2015 Photograph: Reuters

cards.title: Alain de Botton / London is becoming a bad version of Dubai
cards.rawTitle: London is becoming a bad version of Dubai

item.title: Alain de Botton: 'London is becoming a bad version of Dubai'
item.trailText: London is on the verge of being ruined for all future generations, says Alain de Botton. With a whopping 260 towers in the pipeline, here's why we're right to be nervous – and how we can stop this clear desecration of the capital city
item.standFirst: London is on the verge of being ruined for all future generations, says Alain de Botton. With a whopping 260 towers in the pipeline, no area is safe, as planners, property developers and the mayor's office commit crimes against beauty to create fun buildings. Here's why we're right to be nervous – and how we can stop this clear desecration of the capital city
